article.text: What features would you expect from a fitness tracker over S$100? A colored OLED display, continuous heart rate tracking and the ability to track swimming maybe? The brand new Honor Band 4 offers all of that, and more, at just S$59. In this article, let’s take a quick look at what it offers.

Honor Band 4 comes in a cyan box similar to the one for the Honor Band A2. Inside the box, you will find the Honor Band 4, a proprietary charging connector and a very short micro USB cable. There are also 2 booklets, one for warranty and the other is a quick start guide. Nothing special here.

Firstly, power on the band by connecting it to the charger. Then, you will be asked to download the Huawei Health app. You can find the app by scanning the QR code on the display, or via one of the links below. Android users will also have to install Huawei Mobile Services from the Play Store.

Open the app and register/login to your Huawei account. Once done, tap on the plus icon on top and select “Smart Band”, then “Honor Band 4”. You should see the following icons on the Honor Band 4’s screen. Tap on the tick to pair the band to your phone. Almost done.

Next, it will ask you to set up notifications and other stuff, and lastly update your band’s firmware. The first time I updated it, it took really long but the device stayed cool and used only 10% battery.

On top of viewing of data, there are a few settings that you can change in the app. But before you do that, go set your weight and height under “Me” > “Profile”. To change the band’s settings, tap on the band icon on top. Here, you can select what notifications and functions to show on the band.

There are also 2 important features that you can enable: Huawei TruSleep and continuous heart rate tracking. Both features will drain battery faster, but they can help you take fitness tracking to the next level, so you will want to turn them on. I will be talking more about both of them below.
Overall, the Huawei Health app is well implemented and easy to use. Syncing is really quick too.

Before I get to that beautiful AMOLED display, I want to talk about the straps. It is very flexible and comfortable around your wrist. Holes on both straps allow for greater ventilation. Unlike the Xiaomi’s strap, Honor Band 4’s strap buckle is made of hard plastic, so it wouldn’t break so easily.
In Singapore, there are only 2 colors for the strap: blue and black. But if you so happen to find a nicer one, you can remove and replace it by following the steps below. No tools needed.

To the front is the screen and a capacitive button below it. The colored screen is well-sized for a fitness tracker, plenty sharp and is bright enough to be seen under direct sunlight. Yep, even though it is only S$4 more than the Mi Band 3, its display has colors! Very impressive, Honor.

On top of the default watch face, there are 3 other faces available right now, up from just a total of 2 faces at the launch event. We can expect more to come via future firmware updates. Certain faces can display additional information, like weather and distance traveled for example.

You interact with the display by swiping and tapping on it. Swipe up and down to navigate through different functions and tap to enter. Swipe from the left to go back. Tap the capacitive button below to wake the screen and return to the watch face. Very straightforward.

The display sleeps after ~8s of inactivity, but it will only return to the watch face after ~20s. No need to tap the screen every few seconds to prevent it from going to sleep and ending your interaction. This small attention to detail greatly improved my experience using the Honor Band 4.
The plastic body of Honor Band 4 is matte on the back, clear and glossy on the front. It feels well built. On the rear, we have a heart rate monitor, as well as two metal connectors for charging.

Honor Band 4’s water resistance is rated up to 50m, so you can bring it for a swim. The display wouldn’t register your taps and swipes under water, but you can enable “Rotate to switch screen” to switch page.
So far so good. But how accurate is the Honor Band 4’s step tracking? I compared it with the Mi Band 2, which is a fairly reliable step tracker. Here are the results I got.

For walking and jogging, both bands do an equally excellent job, off by less than 5 steps per 100 steps. Both tend to over count when you start increasing your pace, but the readings are still within acceptable range. For most people, the Honor Band 4’s step tracking is good enough.

There are 2 ways to start a workout on the Honor Band 4 and both records different things. The first way is starting an “exercise” from the app. This method relies on the GPS of your phone to track your movements, while getting heart rate readings from the Honor Band 4.
Use this method if you want to get a mapped out version of your run. The disadvantage to this is that you have to open the app to use it and you can’t use it to track swimming.

The other method is to start a workout from the band. You get to select from a list of 6 activities, including swimming. It will prompt you to set your workout goal, in the form of laps/distance, duration or calories. You can also set an alert for when you hit a certain distance.

During your workout, the band will show the duration and the distance you traveled. To end a workout, press the capacitive button and tap on the stop icon. The band will display a summary of your workout. To view your workout in greater detail, open the app and tap on “Exercise records”.

For workouts in this mode, you get to see the graphs of your heart rate, pace and cadence aka steps per minute. Tap on the share icon on top and the app will create an image with the details of your workout, which you can save and share. There are a couple of designs you can choose from.

By default, continuous heart rate monitoring is off. So the Honor Band 4 will only record your heart rate when you tap “Heart rate” on the display. To record it throughout the day, enable continuous heart rate monitoring in the app. Note that this uses the battery much quicker.

Since my Lifesense Band 2 also supports this feature, I decided to put them against each other. I wore both bands for a day and here are their results. The shapes of both graphs and readings at rest are similar. However, the difference comes when I start to exercise and my heart rate goes above 100 bpm.
L - Honor Band 4, R - Lifesense Band 2

At the peaks, Honor Band 4’s reading was around 160, while Lifesense Band 2’s was below 140. Considering my age and my pace, the Honor Band 4’s reading made more sense. Also, Lifesense’s heart rate readings increased a little late into my run, so I would say the Honor Band 4 is more accurate.
Both are not medical devices, so take their readings with a pinch of salt.

To make full use of the Honor Band 4’s sleep tracking capability, enable Huawei TruSleep in the app. How well does it track your sleep? To test that, I put it against the Mi Band 2 and Lifesense Band 2.

Lifesense Band 2 got the start time wrong, while the other 2 were pretty close. For end time, Honor Band 4 was right on the dot. Mi Band 2 was too early and Lifesense Band 2 was 5 minutes too late. While the other 2 only measured deep and light sleep, the Honor Band 4 also measured REM sleep.
L - Honor Band 4, M - Mi Band 2, R - Lifesense Band 2
Without professional tools, I am unable to tell how accurate the deep and light sleep are for each band. But neither of them are medical devices, so again, take the results with a grain of salt.
Battery & Charging – Not Impressive But Not Bad

How long the Honor Band 4 lasts on a single charge will depend on what features you enable. But if you get a fitness tracker as feature-packed as this, you will probably want to make full use of all of them. So I tested it with all the key features enabled, including TruSleep and continuous heart rate monitor.

With that type of usage, I was able to get 3.5 days of usage. Sounds short, but this is the battery life you can expect from most fitness bands with continuous heart rate monitoring. To charge it, simply connect the band to the included charger. It charges from zero to full in 1.5 hours.
Overall, I am very impressed by what Honor has done with the Honor Band 4. But still, it isn’t flawless. Here are some things I would like to see in the next version of this series.

Firstly, I would like to see Honor either enable scrolling on the capacitive button, or remove it completely. Right now, it can only wake the display and return to the watch face, which feels kind of a pointless.
Secondly, there seems to be a bug with the messages feature where I kept receiving duplicate notifications. It is pretty annoying, so I hope Honor can fix that soon.

Next, I wish Honor would add magnets to the proprietary connector, to make it easier to attach the band for charging. The current one works but isn’t very convenient. A larger battery would also be appreciated.
Lastly, it is nice that we can remove the strap, but there isn’t any other official straps we can replace it with right now. I wish Honor would make more straps with different materials.
